post.author: bpanjavan
post.title: Time is a Limited Resource
post.content:
It’s not particularly unique to software development, but in my opinion it’s far more applicable to software development than many other things. This is one of those logical truths that we all know and have no problem agreeing with. But still, sometimes we need a little reminder of this kind of fact. Because it begins to change all of our decisions in what we do. Thinking back, every 10 hours I spent playing Halo in college could have been 10 more hours I spent more wisely, studying Operating Systems or Networking (2 subjects I consider myself rather weak in) or something else far more productive to my academia and my career.

It’s not okay to constantly put off something and say “I’ll just do it tomorrow”, because now you’re using tomorrow’s time for something you should have done today. Now I’m not saying you have to be a robot to be successful. Breaks are important, and leisure activities are too. But be productive in what you do. Watching TV is nice, but don’t watch re-runs to the point you’ve memorized the script. Videogames are great, but don’t get into doing the same repetitive thing over and over again (yes I’m talking to you WarCraft junkies).

Now imagine Software Development is like a fun-filled shopping spree. You’ve got Silverlight, Javascript, AJAX, all off in one corner. You’ve got MOSS and Windows SharePoint Services in another. Biztalk in its rightful place. ASP.NET is smack at the entrance when you walk in. The human knowledge capacity so far has been observed to be limitless. No one in the world has ever run out of memory. So theoretically, you have the ability to go around and absorb every piece of knowledge in the store. BUT…you’re on a time limit. So where do you go? Do you rush off at the first thing you see? Do you take 10 seconds to plan exactly what you want? Do you try to run around as fast as you can and get a little of EVERYthing? It’s a bitter reality, but truly the best thing you can do is first grab some of the bear essentials (.NET, HTML, XML, SQL), and then as you’re grabbing those essentials, look around and pick one or 2 things that you really want to invest your time in (one of those corners). Time is a limitted resource so choose wisely how you spend your career.

comment.author: Doyle Quist
comment.content: When you want to move everything around. Most fitted furniture is cut to fit the area of the room it was originally intended for and cannot be easily dismantled and moved to another part of the room without damaging it. It takes a skilled installer time and patience to do and in many cases the labour costs for dismantling, moving and reassembling exceed the replacement costs. Discuss your ideas with your Doors & Things designer and he will advise you whether refurbishment or replacement is right for you.

comment.author: Britt Bomar
comment.content: Who sells houses to Home Resources of Connecticut? All types of people! Any situation where someone would like to sell quickly for cash. These include: trying to sell with an agent with no results, wanting to avoid real estate commissions, inheriting a property, landlords tired of dealing with renters, needing to sell quickly due to divorce, title issues, facing a job transfer, owners behind on payments or dealing with foreclosure, people with houses that need too much repair, neighbors who live next to vacant houses and want them fixed up, and many more reasons! Anyone who wants to deal with a reliable, reputable company who puts integrity above profits and is willing to go the extra mile to ensure a quick closing with minimum hassle.
